message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is only 6 months post menarche, and irregular periods are common in the first few years after. The intense and severe symptoms may be due to dysmenorrhea and can be addressed symptomatically. The patient is not exhibiting other signs of PCOS or pregnancy. Premenstrual dysphoric disorder typically presents with symptoms in the week before menses, which is not described in this case. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is normal development.

Pregnancy is unlikely given the patient’s age and lack of sexual activity. Premenstrual dysphoric disorder is characterized by severe mood symptoms during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, which is not established in this case.
